titlestmt.subtitle: A Guide to his papers at the Indiana University Archives
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Cathy Cooney

change.item: Batch update to change repository name, subject links, preferred citation, and user restrictions.

did.abstract: Nicolas Spulber was a Distinguished Professor of Economics at Indiana University. Born in Romania in 1915, he immigrated to the United States in 1948 and began teaching at IU in 1954. His research interests focused primarily on the Soviet and post-Soviet economy and the functions of states in economic frameworks including centrally planned, developing, and market economies. Spulber continued researching and writing until his death in 2004. The collection consists of his research materials, reports, conference presentations, correspondence, and manuscripts and reviews of his published works.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The correspondence series is closed to researchers due to the presence of a large number of letters of recommendation, but may be made available to researchers if the Archives is contacted well in advance and given time to review the materials. This series is housed in boxes 7 and 8 of the collection.
Advance notice required for access to the collection.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Nicolas Spulber was born in Romania on January 1, 1915. He graduated from the University of Bucharest in 1934 and began working as a journalist. With the beginning of World War II, he moved to France and joined the French resistance before resuming his career in journalism and becoming a French citizen. He met his wife, Pauline, while living in France. They had one son, Daniel, who also became a professor of economics.

Spulber immigrated to the United States in 1948 and earned a Master's degree from the New School for Social Research in 1950 and a Ph.D. in economics from the same institution in 1952. He worked as a research associate at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology from 1952 to 1954 and began working at Indiana University in 1954 and retired in 1980, although he continued to teach the occasional class. He earned a Ford Foundation Fellowship for the 1960-1961 academic year, became a Distinguished Professor in 1974, and served as a senior research scholar for the International Development Research Center (IDRC) from 1967-1972.

Nicolas Spulber was fluent in French, Romanian, English, Russian, German, and Spanish, in addition to having reading knowledge of other languages. He published six of his twenty books after his retirement and continued coming to his office to work every day until late 2003. Spulber died on January 2, 2004.

His primary areas of research interest include the Soviet and post-Soviet economy, and the functions of states in economic frameworks ranging from centrally planned economics to developing economies to market economies.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized in five series: Department of Economics, Research, Publications, Professional organizations, and Correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The collection is organized into five series: Department of Economics, Research, Publications, Professional organizations, and Correspondence. The records span the years 1885 to 2004, with the majority dating between 1946 and 1999.

The Department of Economics series includes materials directly relating to Spulber's faculty role at Indiana University. It contains departmental reports, research proposals, awards, course proposals and syllabi, and Spulber's curriculum vitae. Folders in this series are arranged alphabetically by folder heading.

The Research series includes source material Spulber collected in the course of his research, as well as his notes on that source material. It also contains graphs and tables created by Spulber. Folders in this series are arranged alphabetically by general topic.

The Publications series is further organized into two subseries: Monograph and Non-Monograph. The Monograph subseries contains manuscripts, proofs, outlines, reviews, correspondence, publishing contracts, and copyright documents for many of the works Spulber either wrote or edited. A series of folders relating to The Soviet Economy: Structure, Principles, Problems contain Spulber's research divided by chapter. These materials were grouped in this manner by the creator of the collection and, because they relate to a specific publication, are included in the Publications series rather than the Research series. Folders in this subseries are arranged chronologically by the date of a work's first publication. The Non-Monograph subseries contains reviews and short articles written by Spulber, as well as outlines, documents, and speeches he prepared. Folders in this subseries are arranged alphabetically.

The Professional organizations series includes materials from conferences at which Spulber presented and records from his involvement with the Association for the Study of Soviet-Type Economies (ASTE), the International Development Resource Center (IDRC), and the IDRC's Development, Entrepreneurship and Discrimination (DED) program. A proposal for funding sent to the Ford Foundation in 1965 is also included in this series. Folders in this series are arranged alphabetically.

The Correspondence series includes Spulber's correspondence with various individuals and groups. The entire series is restricted due to the presence of letters of recommendation. Folders in this series are arranged chronologically by year. Some records were processed by the collection's creator and are arranged chronologically.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Additional publications and research materials may be accessed in IUScholarworks
Related photographs may be available in the University Archives Photographs Database

userestrict.head: Usage Restrictions
userestrict.p: The donor(s) of this collection have not transferred their copyrights for the materials to the Trustees of Indiana University. For more information, please contact the Indiana University Archives staff.

The Indiana University Archives respects the intellectual property rights of others and does not claim any copyrights for non-university records, materials in the public domain, or materials for which we do not hold a Deed of Gift. Responsibility for the determination of the copyright status of these materials rests with those persons wishing to reuse the materials. Researchers are responsible for securing permission from copyright owners and any other rights holders for any reuse of these materials that extends beyond fair use or other statutory limitations.

Digital reproductions of archival materials from the Indiana University Archives are made available for noncommercial educational and research purposes only. If you are the copyright holder for any of the digitized materials and have questions about its inclusion on our site, please contact the Indiana University Archivist.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item], Nicolas Spulber papers, Collection C527, Indiana University Archives, Bloomington.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: The materials originally composing accession 97/049 were acquired by the University Archives on September 9, 1979, were transferred to the Lilly Library, and were transferred back to the University Archives on July 2, 1997. The remaining materials were deposited by Prof. Spulber himself.

appraisal.head: Appraisal
appraisal.p: One cubic foot of materials consisting of copies of articles in Russian that were not written by Spulber was discarded. Duplicate materials and records of royalties from published works were also discarded.
